There are two (at least) issues here that could confuse a reliable prediction. 1)	According to the Spectator magazine the Office for National Statistics (ONS) definition of home workers include people who work and live on a farm or stables, or above a pub or shop. Also includes plumbers, hairdressers, electricians etc. that may have a filing cabinet at home that constitutes an office (for tax purposes). 
Therefore, the ONS statistics do not only refer to the minority of home workers in front of a computer, but account for the large number of the self-employed.
The inference here being that the Covid pandemic, while severely having an effect on business volume, would not change the dynamics of the workplace in general. 2)	The use of ‘working from home Exclusively’ rather than ‘mainly from home’ and suggests that office workers working from home (maybe not exclusively) during the pandemic is not a significant number considering the UK Labour force.
In April 2020 (the beginning of the pandemic) the ONS determined that the self-employed constituted 15.3% of the labour force Also, the current unemployment rate as stated by the ONS is 4.9% who are exclusively at home but not working.
In 2020 35.9% of workers reported some level of home working due to the pandemic, but this is only a 9.4% increase from 2019.
Again, this not working ‘exclusively from home’. ONS data show that two thirds of workers did no home working in 2020. A total of 35.9% worked at home to some extent (not exclusively).
64.1% worked exclusively from their job site (away from home) for the whole of 2020. Therefore, as the ONS considers 15.9% of workers to be exclusive home workers, 4.9% are unemployed, this leaves a minority of workers who are normally office based but working exclusively at home during the pandemic to be small and probably hovers around the 20% until the government releases the lockdown measures. The advantages to the employee would be the avoidance of the daily drudgery and cost of commuting and a better life balance (depending on family relations, children, pets etc).
The disadvantages to the employee would the loss of the office camaraderie and peer-based support and learning plus the potential of the company to turn its business into a gig style economy with potential loss in holiday, sickness benefits.
